notes:
1. Major Head Loss

Energy loss due to friction in long straight sections of pipe is called major loss. It is calculated using the Darcy-Weisbach equation.

$$ h_f = f \frac{L}{D} \frac{v^2}{2g} $$
  • $h_f$: Head loss due to friction.
  • $f$: Darcy friction factor (dimensionless).
  • $L$: Length of pipe.
  • $D$: Pipe diameter.
  • $v$: Average flow velocity.
  • $g$: Acceleration due to gravity.

2. Friction Factor (f)

The friction factor depends on the Reynolds number ($Re$) and relative roughness ($\epsilon/D$).

  • Laminar Flow ($Re < 2300$): $f = 64/Re$.
  • Turbulent Flow ($Re > 4000$): Determine $f$ using the Moody Chart or the Colebrook equation.

solvedExamples.question: For laminar flow in a circular pipe, the Darcy friction factor $f$ depends on:

options.text: Both Reynolds number and relative roughness.

solvedExamples.explanation: In the laminar regime, the friction factor is defined analytically as $f = 64/Re$. It is independent of the pipe's surface roughness.
